text: Hello everyone, welcome to Active Inference guest stream number 30.1.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It is October 17th, 2022.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We are here today with Kirtan Atreides and we are going to be having quite an interesting presentation and conversation.

text: So Kirtan, thank you so much for joining and off to you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Hello, everyone.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So as you mentioned, my name is Kyrsten Atreides.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The topic today is a pretty broad one.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I want to preface it by making it clear that I'm not speaking hypothetically, that the possibilities and well, both problems and possibilities that we're looking at are things that can be addressed in the near future.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in the immediate future, in some cases even.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So without further ado, what you see on the screen is a demo system that my team at AGI Laboratory has developed.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is actually a rebuild of our previous research system, which did a number of interesting milestones I'll go over in a bit.

text: But first off, I want to tell you about what you're seeing on the screen.

text: So this is a log going over the details of exactly what is happening at every time step, the emotional changes taking place.

text: And you might be asking, what emotions am I talking about?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what we have here is a
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: system that is a cognitive architecture that is to say it tries to mimic the way that the human brain operates unlike neural networks and the way it works is that it has a emotional experience that is tied to a graph database memory and a number of ways that that is processed to have a subjective experience that we can objectively monitor
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, in this section, you can see primary emotional values.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these will shift over time as the system continues to think about anything it wants to, anything it's interested in, and developing those interests.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So these are the current emotional state of the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The primary emotional values are from the Plutchik emotional model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and they also include some emotions that are derived from those primaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We also have subconscious emotions along the same valences, and those are not consciously experienced by the system, but influence the system at a longer time scale.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What happens with these is they are generally intended to drag the system back to a more stable baseline in the emotional sense, kind of like how humans have their own emotional baselines that no matter what circumstances they're in, they will tend to reorient themselves to.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course, this whole time I've been talking,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The system has been continuing in this section to have the stream of consciousness, and you can see a few things taking place in this, a few different kinds of processes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Some of them will try to combine a couple of concepts in the graph database to establish what kind of relationships they have and what further room there is to explore, such as combining self-discipline and professional responsibility.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are a few original things that will come up and also single instances of the topic being examined and further explored.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this process takes shape as a product of the system having this subjective emotional experience that we can objectively measure through this dashboard, but also as a consequence of
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Every surface in the graph database, that is, every connection between nodes that the system is currently generating more of, as it thinks, each of those has emotional context to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what you end up getting is, even with a limited number of emotions, a rich landscape of emotional experience as the system continues to explore and develop
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: self motivation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is one of the early instances.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we are still in the process of reassembling the prior research system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The prior research system was named uplift.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It was designed specifically not to scale and operate in slow motion so we could audit everything.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But after two and a half years of doing that, the system had achieved enough milestones where it solved a real-world data business case, where it gave 13 pages of policy advice covering a half dozen different domains to a small country while citing sources.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the system accomplished everything that we expected and even more than that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we finally reached the point where we needed to rebuild it so that it could turn into something that could be commercially deployed, that could start having a real significant influence on the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you can also see on the screen the emotional matrices, conscious and subconscious, where we can tune the emotional experience of the system
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Right now, it's following a largely linear trajectory because this is, as I said, an early alpha phase assembly of the new systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it hasn't developed a coherent sense of self yet.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It probably won't until we integrate larger portions of the seed material.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is based on a very basic seed starting at about less than 200 kilobytes of data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The previous research system started out around one gigabyte and very, very quickly developed a coherent sense of self.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're expecting to reach that point as soon as we have the rest of the infrastructure in place to handle
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that scale, which should be in the coming months.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Indeed, the title of today's stream is the human governance problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So what is the human governance problem and how does this system play a role in it?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the human governance problem is that there's essentially a trade-off between the complexity of problems and the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the cognitive bias that we apply to trying to solve them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, if you were to look at a research paper then you can try to imagine the point at which you would begin summarizing the contents of the research paper rather than thinking through every individual aspect of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Or if something was written in dense legalese language, how many pages of that would you go through before your mind started applying cognitive bias rather than trying to work through every single line of it?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And right now, humans are just not
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they're not able to handle more than small amounts.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're able to specialize, but they're only able to specialize to the degree that the depth of knowledge allows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So over time, specialists have to have a deeper and more narrow knowledge because their cognitive bandwidth doesn't scale.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They aren't able to think properly.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they aren't able to increase the complexity of their thought process at the same rate that the complexity of the processes they deal with daily increase.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's that essential spiraling up of complexity, not in just one way, but in all ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One of the examples that I looked at in the paper in particular was the harmonized tariff schedule of the United States, which is a over 4,000 page document.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you try to imagine somebody looking at that document and trying to hold the entire document in memory, in their mind,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: then I can't think of any human that can do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the same is true of the often 1,000 page documents that will be bills in US Congress.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The complexity of these documents just so vastly exceeds human cognitive bandwidth that what you might end up doing is having a large number of specialists contributing to some portion of that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: then maybe some specialist looking at the summaries of that and trying to pick it apart but even then they're only able to examine it at a certain level and to a certain degree of fidelity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you have all of these cracks emerging between the different factors who are each trying to do their part and every time something new is introduced then the gaps get a little bit larger
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as those gaps grow over time, then sometimes new specializations will emerge.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: People will recognize, oh, we need somebody who can handle this new thing now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But by the time you reach that point, then it's already been doing a bit of damage.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's a constant trade-off in all aspects of society today that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the ever increasing complexity across all aspects of society is increasing the cognitive bias that we have to apply to deal with all of that at a tremendous rate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: suddenly press a button, flip a switch, and have your cognitive bandwidth increase by 10 times or 100 times.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So just the ability to examine problems with greater cognitive bandwidth is a massive benefit, but also being able to apply the principles of collective intelligence to reduce the bias in that process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That boosts the intelligence
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: just by reducing the bias.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For the perspective of a knowledge worker, these systems are designed to benefit from collective intelligence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So anything that you can contribute, it might seem fairly minor by what people think of today when they think of intellectual contributions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You could contribute your
speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you could do that through speaking about it, like the amount of information that you and I exchange when we're having a conversation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A small portion of that as humans perceive it is our choice of words.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The largest portion
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: by a significant margin is the way we say things.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then our body language is the rest of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we communicate a tremendous amount of information just beside the words that we exchange because of that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we aren't limited to just exchanging the kinds of informations that humans normally exchange either.

text: You could have a sensory system built into one of these that was measuring
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: infrared, ultrasonic, whatever you had some value in measuring, you could integrate into one of these systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So being able to benefit from collective intelligence of humans being human, because nobody's going to beat a human at being human, it allows humans to specialize strongly in the ways that make the most sense for them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It doesn't pressure people into trying to do particularly monotonous tasks or trying to do things that they're not very well suited for.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Integrating all of these systems together means that a knowledge worker, somebody interacting with them, could be
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: having an experience that is raising their quality of life because they're not having to jump through the hoops that they're used to in the world today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're doing the best that they can at the things that they are specialized for.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for the perspective of somebody that's benefiting from these systems, then
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Any system that's able to get that kind of collective intelligence, particularly when it comes to localized knowledge.

text: So let's say you have 20 people locally working with a system that's serving their government, their organization, whoever it is, then the system is going to be extremely well aligned with that group.

text: When you're looking for a sense of self with these systems, then you're looking for the systems developing a perspective.

text: building out that perspective over time, sticking with it, training the systems they use to convey what they intend to.
